prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use a single continuum mode, with a recommended default band.

We request the angular-resolution of 300.0 mas, which is comparable to the median of angular size of 2 < z < 6 submm galaxies estimated by ALMA. With this requested angular-resolution, we could resolve at least some of our targets; if not we could put tight constraint on the source size of our targets. On the other hand, even if the target source is largely extended than 300.0 mas and the flux per one beam decresed to the 50% of total flux, we can still detect our target with the requested sensitivity.
Therefore we can say that the requested angular resolution is suitable for our science goal.

The targets of this science goal, SXDF-ALMA 01 and SXDF-ALMA 02 are close to each other and spatially blended in the image obtained by Herschel/SPIRE at 7.5 GHz (which is the same as band 9 frequency). The SPIRE observations are limited by source confusion, and therefore only a fraction of total SPIRE flux should be coming from our targets, SXDF-ALMA01 and SXDF-ALMA 02. However, by using our comlogical galaxy formation model, we found that the total SPIRE flux at 7.5 GHz is likely to be dominated by submm birght sources (> 1 mJy at 1.1mm), in the case that multiple submm bright sources are in the same error circle of SPIRE image. we estimated the contribution fraction from individual galaxies to the total (i.e., spatially-blended) flux. If we assumed that the ratio of band 9 flux of SXDF-ALMA01 and SXDF-ALMA02 is 2:1, which is the same as the ratio of their 1.1 mm flux, the expected band 9 flux of them become 15.4 mJy and 7.7 mJy, for SXDF-ALMA01 and SXDF-ALMA02, respectively. This flux level will be detected with S/N > 10 with the requested sensitivity.
Furthermore, even if the target galaxies are extended than the primary beam size (0''.3) and the flux in one beam decreases to about 50% of total flux, still we can detect our targets with S/N > 5.
Therefore we can say that the requested sensitivity is reasonable.
We use a single continuum mode, with a recommended default band.

We request the angular-resolution of 300.0 mas, which is comparable to the angular size of 2 < z < 6 submm galaxies estimated by ALMA. With this requested angular-resolution, we could resolve at least some of our targets; if not we could put tight constraint on the source size of our targets. On the other hand, even if the target source is largely extended than 300.0 mas and the flux per one beam decresed to the 50% of total flux, we can still detect our target with the requested sensitivity.
Therefore we can say that the requested angular resolution is suitable for our science goal.

The expected peak continuum flux of each source written here are about the half of the flux obtained by Herschel/SPIRE at the same frequency with ALMA band 9, 7.5GHz. Under this assumption, our targets will be detected with S/N > 10.
The SPIRE observations are limited by source confusion, and therefore only a fraction of total SPIRE flux should be coming from our targets. By using our comlogical galaxy formation model, we estimated the contribution fraction from individual galaxies to the total (i.e., spatially-blended) flux. As a result, we found that almost all of simulated galaxies, which are bright as our targets, has a large contribution (> 50%) to the total flux.
Furthermore, even if the target galaxies are extended than the primary beam size (0''.3) and the flux in one beam decreases to about 50% of total flux, still we can detect our targets with S/N > 5.
Therefore we can say that the requested sensitivity is reasonable.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SSA22 bright sources
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Bright sources selected from SSA22 protocluster region.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use a single continuum mode, with a recommended default band.

We request the angular-resolution of 300.0 mas, which is comparable to the angular size of 2 < z < 6 SMGs estimated by ALMA. With this requested angular-resolution, we could resolve at least some of our targets; if not we could put tight constraint on the source size of our targets. On the other hand, even if the target source is largely extended than 300.0 mas and the flux per one beam decresed to the 50% of total flux, we can still detect our target with the requested sensitivity.
Therefore we can say that the requested angular resolution is suitable for our science goal.

The expected peak continuum flux of each source written here are about the half of the flux obtained by Herschel/SPIRE at the same frequency with ALMA band9, 7.5GHz. Under this assumption, our targets will be detected with S/N > 10.
The SPIRE observations are limited by source confusion, and therefore only a fraction of total SPIRE flux should be coming from our targets. By using our comlogical galaxy formation model, we estimated the contribution fraction from individual galaxies to the total (i.e., spatially-blended) flux. As a result, we found that almost all of simulated galaxies, which are bright as our targets, has a large contribution (> 50%) to the total flux.
Furthermore, even if the target galaxies are extended than the primary beam size (0''.3) and the flux in one beam decreases to about 50% of total flux, still we can detect our targets with S/N > 5.
Therefore we can say that the requested sensitivity is reasonable.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SSA22 faint sources
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Relatively fainter sources selected from SSA22 protocluster region.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use a single continuum mode, with a recommended default band.

We request the angular-resolution of 300.0 mas, which is comparable to the angular size of 2 < z < 6 SMGs estimated by ALMA. With this requested angular-resolution, we could resolve at least some of our targets; if not we could put tight constraint on the source size of our targets. On the other hand, even if the target source is largely extended than 300.0 mas and the flux per one beam decresed to the 50% of total flux, we can still detect our target with the requested sensitivity.
Therefore we can say that the requested angular resolution is suitable for our science goal.

The expected peak continuum flux of each source written here are about the half of the flux obtained by Herschel/SPIRE at the same frequency with ALMA band 9, 7.5GHz. Under this assumption, our targets will be detected with S/N > 10.
The SPIRE observations are limited by source confusion, and therefore only a fraction of total SPIRE flux should be coming from our targets. By using our comlogical galaxy formation model, we estimated the contribution fraction from individual galaxies to the total (i.e., spatially-blended) flux. As a result, we found that almost all of simulated galaxies, which are bright as our targets, has a large contribution (> 50%) to the total flux.
Furthermore, even if the target galaxies are extended than the primary beam size (0''.3) and the flux in one beam decreases to about 50% of total flux, still we can detect our targets with S/N > 5.
Therefore we can say that the requested sensitivity is reasonable.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose the band 9 observations of the ten SMGs which are located in the peak era of cosmic star formation, 2 < z < 3. Our targets are already observed by ALMA in single band (band 6 or 7); however we need to observe the peak of dust SED to know their physical properties such as star foramtion rate. By ALMA band 9 follow-up observation, we aim to unveil the true nature of these high-z SMGs.
We selected the target sample from three survey fields, SXDF-UDS-CANDELS-ALMA, ALESS, and SSA22 protocluster region, where deep multi-band data are available. The redshift of all sample galaxies are determined spectroscopically, and therefore we can resolve the degeneracies between the redshift and the parameters related to dust SED (e.g., dust temperature). Furthermore, we could also estimate the angular size of our targets, thanks to the high angular-resolution of ALMA.
Through the proposed observations, we will obtain many fruiful informations on the nature of SMGs in the peak era of cosmic starformation, such as dust mass, dust temperature, SFR, and the size of star forming region. These informations will give significant impact on the understandings of cosmic galaxy formation history.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
